For years, we have heard that that 1-in-4
or 1-in-5 college women are victims of rape

5.text:
or sexual assault. But the studies behind
the statistic tended to be agenda driven and

12.text:
unscientific.  But now, according to hundreds
of news stories, there’s a new, more comprehensive

17.text:
survey that confirms epidemic levels of sexual
predation on campus. Could these researchers

23.text:
be right? That’s coming up next on the Factual
Feminist.

27.text:
Last month, the Association of American Universities
released the findings of its massive new report

34.text:
on campus sexual assault. The authors surveyed
students at 27 colleges across the US and

41.text:
found that 23 percent of female college seniors—nearly
one in four—reported that they had experienced

49.text: unwanted sexual contact since entering college.

52.text:
First, the survey was offered to 780,000 students,
but only 150,000 students filled it out. That’s

60.text:
a response rate of only 19%. The authors caution
in the study that estimates may be too high

67.text:
because of “non-response bias”—that
is, because students who have been sexually

71.text:
assaulted may be more likely to fill out a
survey about sexual assault than those who

76.text:
have not. The authors also warn that their
findings are “not representative” and

80.text:
should not be extrapolated to anything outside
their frame.

85.text:
Like past surveys on campus sexual assault,
respondents were not asked whether or not

90.text:
they had ever been raped or sexually assaulted.
Such direct questions are known to yield low

95.text:
numbers of victimization. Instead, the authors
asked if students experienced a range of behaviors

101.text:
from forced penetration to kissing to unwanted
touching or grabbing. If someone rubbed up

107.text:
against you in a sexual way at a party—that
could count.  Using such definitions, the

113.text:
authors calculated the rate of college females
experiencing unwanted sexual contact at each

117.text:
of the schools surveyed.   The authors warn
that it would be “over simplistic” or

123.text:
“misleading” to conclude that 20-25% of
students are victims of sexual assault nationwide

127.text:
according to their findings. Well, that didn’t
stop the media . “Unwanted sexual contact”

133.text:
became “sexual assault”—and the journalists
were off to the races.

136.text:
But Jennifer Freyd, a professor at the University
of Oregon and an expert on “trauma betrayal”

137.text:
was biased toward victims. Wrong, says Freyd—
“those who were sexually assaulted are more

138.text:
likely to avoid the survey. In fact, she says,
survivors of sexual violence know that avoidance

140.text:
is a hallmark of post-trauma response.”
She could be right. But there is another factor

141.text:
that undermines the report that she is forgetting--call
it advocacy bias.  At nearly every college

143.text:
It’s far from perfect, but the best data
we have on sexual assault comes from the Justice

145.text:
Department, Bureau of Justice Statistics.
It find that approximately 1 in 53 women will

151.text:
be victims of rape or sexual assault while
in college. That is still too many victims—but

156.text:
it’s vastly different from 1 in 4.   And
according to the latest data from the FBI,

161.text:
the US rape rate fell to a 41 year low in
2014.

165.text:
And even though politicians, journalists,
and celebrities are fixated on the supposed

171.text:
campus rape epidemic, females are who are
not enrolled in college are actually more

176.text:
likely to be victims of sexual violence than
college women.

180.text:
The Factual Feminist verdict? As its own authors
admit, the new campus rape survey is flawed,

187.text:
it asked vaguely worded questions to a non
representative sample of students who chose

192.text:
to participate. It is also likely to suffer
from advocacy bias.  Rape culture politics

193.text:
have not only brought panic to the campus,
they may have made it impossible to carry

195.text:
out meaningful research. This is unfortunate,
because even though activists often exaggerate

198.text:
the numbers, sexual assault on campus is a
serious problem. There are victims on campus

203.text:
who need protection.  We badly need better
policies and practices. Misleading research

212.text:
Do you think I am right to suggest that activists
might use the surveys as a political weapon

216.text:
to advance their cause?  Let me know in the
comments. And if you found this video useful,
